title: My Favorite Gray Background & How to Use It
summary: Photographer Lindsay Adler explains how to choose the right gray background based on tonality and warmth, reveals her favorite versatile option (Fashion Gray), and demonstrates lighting and post-processing techniques to change its appearance from light gray to black or cool tones.

steps.action: Evaluate background options based on two categories: Tonality (lightness/darkness) and Warmth/Coolness.
Select 'Fashion Gray' for a versatile, slightly cool and neutral starting point.
Feather the key light by angling it away from the background to reduce spill, making the gray appear darker.
Feather the light extremely by pointing it almost completely across the frame to turn the background nearly black.
Place a V-Flat between the light source and the background to block all light, creating a pure black background.
Add a white V-Flat on the opposite side of the light to bounce fill light into the subject's shadows.
Use the Color Balance tool in post-processing to cool down shadows (blue) and warm up highlights (yellow) to color grade the neutral background.

key_takeaways: Fashion Gray is a versatile middle-ground choice that is neutral enough to be easily manipulated.
You can change the brightness of a background significantly just by feathering the light (changing its angle).
V-Flats are useful for both blocking light (to darken backgrounds) and reflecting light (to fill shadows).
Neutral gray backgrounds are ideal for color grading in post-production as they easily take on cool or warm tints.
